ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Uncompensated Left Peripheral Vestibular Hypofunction with Central Cerebellar Impairment
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: VNG showed left caloric weakness (peripheral) and DBN/abnormal pursuit (central). MRI confirmed cerebellar atrophy.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Meniere's Disease
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: History of diagnosis, but ruled out due to lack of fluctuating hearing loss and inconsistent symptoms.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Vestibular Migraine
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Considered due to symptoms but patient did not meet diagnostic criteria.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Positional symptoms present, but nystagmus was persistent DBN rather than typical BPPV nystagmus.

ordered_list.rationale_short: Assess hearing sensitivity given history of hearing loss.
Evaluate vestibular function due to dizziness and gait disturbance.
Evaluate central vestibular function and VOR suppression.
Visualize brain structure to rule out space-occupying lesions or degeneration.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Audiometry revealed mild low-frequency sensorineural hearing loss bilaterally with excellent speech recognition. Immittance testing was normal, ruling out middle ear pathology.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Mild SNHL at 250-2000 Hz rising to normal at 3000-6000 Hz bilaterally; Left ear mild SNHL at 8000 Hz.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: SRT 20 dB HL bilaterally; WRS 90% (Right) and 100% (Left).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Present at normal sensation levels bilaterally.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Vestibular and medical evaluation revealed a 'double hit' pathology: a peripheral left vestibular hypofunction and central vestibular impairment (DBN, abnormal pursuit, VOR suppression failure). MRI confirmed cerebellar atrophy, likely alcohol-related.

tests.name: Videonystagmography (VNG)
tests.result_summary: Persistent DBN in center gaze increasing with lateral/downward gaze; abnormal smooth pursuit; 49% left unilateral weakness; 49% right directional preponderance.

tests.name: Rotary Chair
tests.result_summary: Abnormal phase leads at 0.01 and 0.02 Hz; abnormal VOR suppression at 0.04 and 0.08 Hz.

tests.name: cVEMP
tests.result_summary: Normal N1-P1 latency and amplitude values bilaterally.

tests.name: Neuro-ophthalmology Exam
tests.result_summary: Confirmed DBN, positive Daroff sign, and subtle scanning speech (ataxic dysarthria).

tests.name: MRI Brain
tests.result_summary: Mild diffuse cerebellar and cerebral atrophy.

counseling_actions: Explain 'double hit' pathology involving both inner ear weakness and cerebellar processing issues
Counsel on the impact of alcohol use on cerebellar function and compensation
Discuss fall prevention and home safety

red_flags_present: Abnormal smooth pursuit and VOR suppression

escalation.rationale_short: Central vestibular signs (DBN, ataxia) require specialist evaluation to confirm diagnosis and manage central pathology.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor response to medication and therapy, and ensure home safety.

expected_outcome: Patient reported a reduction in the symptoms of oscillopsia with lateral gaze following baclofen prescription.
Patient reported a decrease in symptoms following vestibular and balance therapy.
Safety issues (risk of falls) were addressed and an appointment was made for OT to visit the home.
